title: High-Yield Summary Table of Herpesviruses
content:
Summary of Upper Limb Muscles

The muscles of the upper limb are responsible for movement and stability of the shoulder, arm, forearm, and hand. They can be classified into different groups based on their location and function.

1. Shoulder Muscles

These muscles move and stabilize the shoulder joint (glenohumeral joint).

  • Deltoid → Abducts the arm (raises it away from the body).

  • Rotator Cuff Muscles (SITS muscles):

    • Supraspinatus → Initiates arm abduction.
    • Infraspinatus → Externally rotates the arm.
    • Teres Minor → Externally rotates the arm.
    • Subscapularis → Internally rotates the arm.

  • Trapezius → Elevates, retracts, and rotates the scapula.

  • Latissimus Dorsi → Extends, adducts, and internally rotates the arm.

  • Pectoralis Major → Adducts and internally rotates the arm.

  • Pectoralis Minor → Stabilizes the scapula.

  • Serratus Anterior → Protracts the scapula (pulls it forward).

2. Arm Muscles

Divided into anterior (flexor) and posterior (extensor) compartments.

Anterior Compartment (Flexors) – Innervated by Musculocutaneous Nerve

  • Biceps Brachii → Flexes the elbow and supinates the forearm.
  • Brachialis → Primary elbow flexor.
  • Coracobrachialis → Flexes and adducts the arm.

Posterior Compartment (Extensors) – Innervated by Radial Nerve

  • Triceps Brachii → Extends the elbow.
  • Anconeus → Assists in elbow extension.

3. Forearm Muscles

Divided into anterior (flexor/pronator) and posterior (extensor/supinator) compartments.

Anterior Compartment (Flexors/Pronators) – Innervated by Median & Ulnar Nerves

  • Superficial Layer:

    • Pronator Teres (pronates the forearm).
    • Flexor Carpi Radialis (flexes and abducts the wrist).
    • Palmaris Longus (flexes the wrist).
    • Flexor Carpi Ulnaris (flexes and adducts the wrist).

  • Intermediate Layer:

    • Flexor Digitorum Superficialis (flexes fingers at proximal joints).

  • Deep Layer:

    • Flexor Digitorum Profundus (flexes fingers at distal joints).
    • Flexor Pollicis Longus (flexes the thumb).
    • Pronator Quadratus (pronates the forearm).

Posterior Compartment (Extensors/Supinators) – Innervated by Radial Nerve

  • Superficial Layer:

    • Brachioradialis (flexes the elbow despite being in the extensor compartment).
    • Extensor Carpi Radialis Longus & Brevis (extend and abduct the wrist).
    • Extensor Digitorum (extends fingers).
    • Extensor Digiti Minimi (extends the little finger).
    • Extensor Carpi Ulnaris (extends and adducts the wrist).

  • Deep Layer:

    • Supinator (supinates the forearm).
    • Abductor Pollicis Longus (abducts the thumb).
    • Extensor Pollicis Longus & Brevis (extend the thumb).
    • Extensor Indicis (extends the index finger).

4. Hand Muscles

Divided into thenar (thumb), hypothenar (little finger), and intrinsic hand muscles.

Thenar Muscles (Thumb Movement) – Innervated by Median Nerve

  • Abductor Pollicis Brevis (abducts the thumb).
  • Flexor Pollicis Brevis (flexes the thumb).
  • Opponens Pollicis (allows thumb opposition).

Hypothenar Muscles (Little Finger Movement) – Innervated by Ulnar Nerve

  • Abductor Digiti Minimi (abducts the little finger).
  • Flexor Digiti Minimi (flexes the little finger).
  • Opponens Digiti Minimi (brings the little finger towards the thumb).

Intrinsic Hand Muscles – Fine Finger Movements

  • Lumbricals (flex metacarpophalangeal joints and extend interphalangeal joints).
  • Interossei (help with finger adduction and abduction).

Summary Table

Region

Main Muscles

Function

Innervation

Shoulder

Deltoid, Rotator Cuff, Trapezius

Shoulder movement & stability

Axillary, Suprascapular, Spinal Accessory

Arm (Flexors)

Biceps Brachii, Brachialis

Elbow Flexion

Musculocutaneous

Arm (Extensors)

Triceps Brachii

Elbow Extension

Radial

Forearm (Flexors)

Flexor Digitorum Profundus, Flexor Carpi Radialis

Wrist & Finger Flexion

Median & Ulnar

Forearm (Extensors)

Extensor Digitorum, Extensor Carpi Ulnaris

Wrist & Finger Extension

Radial

Hand (Thenar)

Opponens Pollicis, Abductor Pollicis Brevis

Thumb Movement

Median

Hand (Hypothenar)

Abductor Digiti Minimi, Flexor Digiti Minimi

Little Finger Movement

Ulnar

Key Points

  • Musculocutaneous Nerve → Anterior arm muscles (flexors).
  • Radial Nerve → Posterior arm & forearm muscles (extensors).
  • Median Nerve → Most anterior forearm & thenar muscles.
  • Ulnar Nerve → Most intrinsic hand muscles & some forearm muscles.

This is a simplified overview of upper limb muscles focusing on their main functions and innervations. Let me know if you need more details!
